On a sun-baked road winding through arid plains, a caravan of eleven cloth merchants, heavy with the profits of a bustling market, journeyed homeward. From behind a thicket of thorny scrub, three burly figures emerged, the notorious robbers who styled themselves the "Three Monarchs" of the highway. With menacing clubs and glinting daggers, they ambushed the unsuspecting traders, swiftly disarming them, stripping them of their rich turbans, fine kurtas, and even their humble dhotis, leaving them bare and vulnerable on the dusty ground beside their plundered wares.

The merchants emerge victorious, celebrated as heroes for outwitting their oppressors and turning despair into triumph. Their tale becomes a cautionary reminder of humility and cunning.
